oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Cedar Hill Rosenwald School: close-up front view
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Color photograph of the one-story white frame school building with a side red gable roof. It features three chimneys and a bell tower in the center of the roof. It resembles the traditional two-teacher floor plan. The central front gable extension would have been the industrial room and on either side were classrooms. All three rooms feature a chimney. The classrooms feature two one over one light double hung windows. The two classroom entrances are located on either side of the industrial room on the facade. The industrial room is characterized by four twelve over twelve light double hung windows with transoms above for additional light.

The Cedar Hill School was built with support of the Julius Rosenwald fund with funds allocated for budget year 1929-30. Total cost of construction was $5750.00 with funds contributed by African American community, the public, and Rosenwald. The school was a three teacher design plan built on four acres of land.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: African American schools -- Tennessee;Julius Rosenwald Fund -- Buildings
